Gaborone, the capital, is a small town,
and offers theatre, a few hotels, bars, restaurants, a couple of discos, and a small downtown with well-stocked stores. There, Americans find they are not as "deprived" as they
thought they would be in a Third World nation.
The major deficits, to my mind, are the lack of
some of my favorite foods: pizza, "ethnic"
foods (most of which can be sort of reproduced
in one's own kitchen) and crabs.
We spent about two months in Gaborone,
learning the language, Setswana, and about
Tswana culture, from a group of young Botswana teachers. We managed to learn a little
Setswana, a fair amount about the traditional
Tswana culture which is predominant in the
villages, and a lot about how to live an enjoyable
life in Botswana. We were treated to two weeks
of village living, scattered among very rural,
traditional families who generally spoke no
English and had none of life's little luxuries that
I took so much for granted. There I learned
what it was like to haul water from a considerable distance, warm it over a wood fire, take a

sponge bath, and wash my hair with one scant
bucketful.
I was also forced to pick up much more
Setswana, and learned to deal with the major
hardship of village life: boredom. There's little
work to do in the winter, and the women do
most of that—grinding sorghum, fetching water
and wood, cooking, and caring for the kids.
Some of my feminist views have been
slightly altered. I don't like to see all the hard
work the women do here (which includes most
of the farming), but I have a new understanding
of polygamy, which I used to think ridiculously
unjust. But in Botswana, adult women significantly outnumber adult men (due to varying
birth rates, death rates, and emigration). This
used to be a polygamous society, but that's
illegal now. To the detriment of women, the
men have adapted. They have mistresses, who
get pregnant, but may be left entirely on their
own in taking care of all their fatherless children. They may be lucky ever to find a legal
husband who will help care for the kids. Three
cheers for the missionaries' civilizing influence!

The men's major duty is to make frequent
forays to the cattle post to look after their
most prized possessions. Cattle for the Botswana are what a white-collar job, money in the
bank, a nice stock portfolio, a home in the
suburbs, and two new cars are for Americans:
wealth, security, and status. You would no
more ask a Botswana how many cattle he had
than ask an American how much money he had
in the bank. But it is of prime importance.
About half of all families have no cattle,
and most have less than 10. Some families may
have herds ranging into the tens of thousands.
People who live in obvious wealth—the government ministers and professional people with nice
homes and Mercedes Benzes—can be counted on
to have vast herds. In fact, many young Botswana men aspire to a good education and a wellpaying job so that they can buy more cattle.
But the odd thing is that you can't necessarily,
tell the cattle baron from the cattle-less peon. A
man with 10,000 head of cattle may live in the
same sort of rondoval (mud hut), wear the same
sort of old, faded clothes, and eat the same
sorghum porridge as his destitute neighbor. And
you'd never know about his assets, until one day
he sells a couple hundred cattle and parks a
Mercedes Benz in front of his rondoval.
That's what I find in the village of Mahalapyl, where I live now. Though there are more
than 20,000 people here, it's called a village
because it is predominantly "traditional."
We're on the rail line and main road, so we have
a little semi-urban downtown of general stores,
cafes, groceries, and little shops, but there are no
industries or office buildings, and most people
are farmers and cattle holders.
I live in a one-room, thatched-roof mud
hut, deep in the village. I lack both running
water and electricity. • I share the house with
ants and lizards, and share the outhouse with
three-inch-long flying cockroaches. People in
general share the village space with cattle,
donkeys, goats, sheep, and children. A Peace
Corps colleague lives next door to me, and we
are the only whites in our part of town. So
we've made friends with our neighbors, improved on our Setswana, and learned to relax
over home-brewed beer in the local "shebeens."
It takes me 35 minutes to walk to work
during the dry season, when I can cross the dry
river bed; 45 minutes during the rainy season
when the river is full and I have to cross on the
bridge. I get up just before dawn, and go to bed
around 9:30 p.m.
On the weekends, if I want to, I can go to
one of three bars, to Chick's Disco (with its
12-record repertoire and partially mirrored ball),
or invite friends over for an American dinner.
Entertaining with dinner here, and eating

in general, is a delight: with so many cattle
around, I can buy more steak than I can eat at
one meal with 75 cents. I can have a steak
barbecue bash and spend only a few dollars. I've
also found that I like mealie-meal and "fat
cakes" (fried dough). I eat oranges all winter,
mangoes all summer, and put on weight.
People here eat only one thing I would
describe as disgusting: dried caterpillars. But
most people understand when I decline to eat
them. If they seem surprised, I tell them I eat
crabs. They laugh uproariously, make faces, and
the point has been made.
Cultural adjustment took a little longer.
It is imperative to pause and greet everyone you
pass, and to greet anyone you deal with in a
store or business. Failure to do so gets you
slow, cold service and a bad reputation. That, I
can deal with—it is a pleasant, charming custom.
What I can't deal with is the sharing aspect of
the culture. Those who have wealth are expected to share with those who don't. This manifests itself when strangers greet you and ask for
money in the same breath. This invariably puts
me in a bad mood, and it happens at least thrice
a day. On a Peace Corps living allowance, one
could soon get nickled and dimed to death, so I
don't ever give in: I feign ignorance of Setswana
to old ladies; to able-bodied, healthy adults I
say I have no money (a blatant lie is more
acceptable than a frank refusal). To little kids, I
either refuse (if I'm in a good mood), or I
threaten to beat them (if I'm in a bad mood).
It's mostly a cultural shock to my system. It's
unnerving. Back home, if a stranger asks you for
money, he is either a) demanding it at the point
of a gun, b) a Moonie, or c) over 80, blind or
crippled, and playing the accordion. Here the
guy who just got out of his Mercedes Benz might
be the one asking for money. That's when I
counter with a request for cattle.
My work is my major challenge/frustration (again depending on my mood.) I must
teach Development Studies (economics) to kids
who, for the most part, barely understand any
English. Yes—money and banking to kids who
conceive of wealth primarily in terms of cattle;
supply and demand, though they live in a
co-operative society; and international trade
where families are almost self-sufficient. Land
here is allocated to each family by the chief, so
my students are baffled by the concept of
property ownership, keystone of capitalist
economic orthodoxy. But I have to teach it.
It's in the syllabus.
I'm learning a lot more than my students.

Palm Sunday: A Blivit Of Vonnegut
BY DAN VITALE
Palm Sunday, Kurt Vonnegut's
thirteenth book and second work of
non-fiction, is subtitled "An Autobiographical Collage." In the introduction,
Vonnegut describes what sort of structure
such a collage might have: "This book
combines the tidal power of a major
novel with the bone-rattling immediacy
of front-line journalism--which is old stuff
now, God knows, God knows. But I have
also intertwined the flashy enthusiasms of
musical theater, the lethal left jab of the
short story, the sachet of personal letters,
the oompah of American history, and
oratory in the bow-wow style." He then
goes on to propose a generic name for
this type of book: blivit, which he
loosely defines as "two pounds of shit in
a one-pound bag."
Actually, Palm Sunday falls
somewhere between the two descriptions.
In essence, it is a collection of essays,
speeches, fictions and non-fictions (some
previously published, others not), suspended from a running narrative which
attempts to keep them strung together.
The effect is not unlike laundry on a
clothesline; unfortunately, however,some
of the clothes are cleaner than others.
Among the more interesting
"bits" of the collage are: "The Noodle
Factory," a speech given in October 1976
during the dedication of a library at
Connecticut College; "How to Write
with Style," an essay written for an
International Paper Company advertising ,
campaign; a self-interview originally published in the Paris Review; and "Palm
Sunday," a sermon delivered at St.
Clement's Episcopal Church in New York
City in 1980. What makes these pieces so
fascinating is how well each reveals some
facet of Vonnegut's mind and character.
Each is a testament to the earnestness of

his ideas and the simple elegance of his
style. Some examples:
"Film is a perfect prescription for
people who will not or cannot read, and
have no imagination. Since they have no
imagination, those people can now be
shown actors and scenery instead--with
appropriate music and all that."
"We are members of an egalitarian
society, so there is no reason for us to
write, in case we are not classically
educated aristocrats, as though we were
classically educated aristocrats."
"If you make people laugh or cry
about little black marks on a sheet of
white paper, what is that but a practical
joke? All the great story lines are great
practical jokes that people fall for over
and over again."
When Palm Sunday reads like this.
it runs as smoothly as a new car. But the
book does have its share of awkward
moments and throwaways. Among these
are an alphabetical list of all of the
writers Vonnegut has met at least once,
which covers a full two and a half pages; a
rejected introduction to a new edition of
Swift's Gulliver's Travels; a mildly interesting short story titled "The Big Space
Fuck;" and a tedious treatment for a
musical comedy based on Stevenson's
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. One long
section, a family history covering four
generations of Vonneguts in America
(written not by Vonnegut but by John
Rauch, the husband of a cousin of
Vonnegut's father) is fairly illuminating
but very difficult to follow. At its most
self-indulgent, the book can be quite bad.
But for the most part, Palm
Sunday is an enjoyable read. One memorable section includes an impassioned
essay on Louis-Ferdinand Celine which
Vonnegut wrote as an introduction to the
Penguin editions of Celine's last three
novels; another features excerpts from

Vonnegut's master's thesis in anthropology, rejected by the University of Chicago,
in which he visually depicts the stories of
Cinderella, the creation, and Kafka's
"Metamorphosis," among others, by
plotting them as graphs on a coordinate
plane.
Thc finest selections included in
Palm Sunday are those concerning
freedom of the press, such as the letter
Vonnegut wrote to Charles McCarthy,
head of the school board of Drake,
North Dakota, which in 1973 banned
Vonnegut's novel Slaughterhouse-Five
from classrooms there; and an editorial
on censorship which appeared in the
Long Island edition of the New York
Times in March 1976. It is in these pieces
that we get the clearest image of what
Vonnegut's life and work mean to him.
He presents himself to McCarthy not so
much as an outraged author but as
a "planetary citizen," deeply hurt by the
suppression of ideas, while in the Times
he gives deeper and more universal
significance to his frustration:
"Whenever ideas are squashed in
this country, literate lovers of the American experiment write careful and intricate explanations of why all ideas must
be allowed to live. It is time for them to
realize that they are attempting to
explain America at its bravest and most
optimistic to orangutangs.
"From now on, I intend to limit
my discourse with dimwitted Savonarolas
to this advice: 'Have somebody read the
First Amendment to the United States
Constitution out loud to you, you
god-damned fool!"'
Overall, Palm Sunday is an uneven

work, an interesting premise slightly weak
in spots but potent nevertheless.
Vonnegut writes:
"By reading the
writings of the most interesting minds
in history, we meditate with our own
minds and theirs as well." This volume
offers the chance to meditate with the
mind of Kurt Vonnegut, writer and
planetary citizen, a chance which if
taken nourishes one's own mind in the
process.

Gaborone, the capital, is a small town,
and offers theatre, a few hotels, bars, restaurants, a couple of discos, and a small downtown with well-stocked stores. There, Americans find they are not as "deprived" as they
thought they would be in a Third World nation.
The major deficits, to my mind, are the lack of
some of my favorite foods: pizza, "ethnic"
foods (most of which can be sort of reproduced
in one's own kitchen) and crabs.
We spent about two months in Gaborone,
learning the language, Setswana, and about
Tswana culture, from a group of young Botswana teachers. We managed to learn a little
Setswana, a fair amount about the traditional
Tswana culture which is predominant in the
villages, and a lot about how to live an enjoyable
life in Botswana. We were treated to two weeks
of village living, scattered among very rural,
traditional families who generally spoke no
English and had none of life's little luxuries that
I took so much for granted. There I learned
what it was like to haul water from a considerable distance, warm it over a wood fire, take a

sponge bath, and wash my hair with one scant
bucketful.
I was also forced to pick up much more
Setswana, and learned to deal with the major
hardship of village life: boredom. There's little
work to do in the winter, and the women do
most of that—grinding sorghum, fetching water
and wood, cooking, and caring for the kids.
Some of my feminist views have been
slightly altered. I don't like to see all the hard
work the women do here (which includes most
of the farming), but I have a new understanding
of polygamy, which I used to think ridiculously
unjust. But in Botswana, adult women significantly outnumber adult men (due to varying
birth rates, death rates, and emigration). This
used to be a polygamous society, but that's
illegal now. To the detriment of women, the
men have adapted. They have mistresses, who
get pregnant, but may be left entirely on their
own in taking care of all their fatherless children. They may be lucky ever to find a legal
husband who will help care for the kids. Three
cheers for the missionaries' civilizing influence!

The men's major duty is to make frequent
forays to the cattle post to look after their
most prized possessions. Cattle for the Botswana are what a white-collar job, money in the
bank, a nice stock portfolio, a home in the
suburbs, and two new cars are for Americans:
wealth, security, and status. You would no
more ask a Botswana how many cattle he had
than ask an American how much money he had
in the bank. But it is of prime importance.
About half of all families have no cattle,
and most have less than 10. Some families may
have herds ranging into the tens of thousands.
People who live in obvious wealth—the government ministers and professional people with nice
homes and Mercedes Benzes—can be counted on
to have vast herds. In fact, many young Botswana men aspire to a good education and a wellpaying job so that they can buy more cattle.
But the odd thing is that you can't necessarily,
tell the cattle baron from the cattle-less peon. A
man with 10,000 head of cattle may live in the
same sort of rondoval (mud hut), wear the same
sort of old, faded clothes, and eat the same
sorghum porridge as his destitute neighbor. And
you'd never know about his assets, until one day
he sells a couple hundred cattle and parks a
Mercedes Benz in front of his rondoval.
That's what I find in the village of Mahalapyl, where I live now. Though there are more
than 20,000 people here, it's called a village
because it is predominantly "traditional."
We're on the rail line and main road, so we have
a little semi-urban downtown of general stores,
cafes, groceries, and little shops, but there are no
industries or office buildings, and most people
are farmers and cattle holders.
I live in a one-room, thatched-roof mud
hut, deep in the village. I lack both running
water and electricity. • I share the house with
ants and lizards, and share the outhouse with
three-inch-long flying cockroaches. People in
general share the village space with cattle,
donkeys, goats, sheep, and children. A Peace
Corps colleague lives next door to me, and we
are the only whites in our part of town. So
we've made friends with our neighbors, improved on our Setswana, and learned to relax
over home-brewed beer in the local "shebeens."
It takes me 35 minutes to walk to work
during the dry season, when I can cross the dry
river bed; 45 minutes during the rainy season
when the river is full and I have to cross on the
bridge. I get up just before dawn, and go to bed
around 9:30 p.m.
On the weekends, if I want to, I can go to
one of three bars, to Chick's Disco (with its
12-record repertoire and partially mirrored ball),
or invite friends over for an American dinner.
Entertaining with dinner here, and eating

in general, is a delight: with so many cattle
around, I can buy more steak than I can eat at
one meal with 75 cents. I can have a steak
barbecue bash and spend only a few dollars. I've
also found that I like mealie-meal and "fat
cakes" (fried dough). I eat oranges all winter,
mangoes all summer, and put on weight.
People here eat only one thing I would
describe as disgusting: dried caterpillars. But
most people understand when I decline to eat
them. If they seem surprised, I tell them I eat
crabs. They laugh uproariously, make faces, and
the point has been made.
Cultural adjustment took a little longer.
It is imperative to pause and greet everyone you
pass, and to greet anyone you deal with in a
store or business. Failure to do so gets you
slow, cold service and a bad reputation. That, I
can deal with—it is a pleasant, charming custom.
What I can't deal with is the sharing aspect of
the culture. Those who have wealth are expected to share with those who don't. This manifests itself when strangers greet you and ask for
money in the same breath. This invariably puts
me in a bad mood, and it happens at least thrice
a day. On a Peace Corps living allowance, one
could soon get nickled and dimed to death, so I
don't ever give in: I feign ignorance of Setswana
to old ladies; to able-bodied, healthy adults I
say I have no money (a blatant lie is more
acceptable than a frank refusal). To little kids, I
either refuse (if I'm in a good mood), or I
threaten to beat them (if I'm in a bad mood).
It's mostly a cultural shock to my system. It's
unnerving. Back home, if a stranger asks you for
money, he is either a) demanding it at the point
of a gun, b) a Moonie, or c) over 80, blind or
crippled, and playing the accordion. Here the
guy who just got out of his Mercedes Benz might
be the one asking for money. That's when I
counter with a request for cattle.
My work is my major challenge/frustration (again depending on my mood.) I must
teach Development Studies (economics) to kids
who, for the most part, barely understand any
English. Yes—money and banking to kids who
conceive of wealth primarily in terms of cattle;
supply and demand, though they live in a
co-operative society; and international trade
where families are almost self-sufficient. Land
here is allocated to each family by the chief, so
my students are baffled by the concept of
property ownership, keystone of capitalist
economic orthodoxy. But I have to teach it.
It's in the syllabus.
I'm learning a lot more than my students.
I teach in a private, community "self-help"
junior secondary school. Here in Botswana, the
best students go to government schools which
also get the best student faculties, and the most
money. Education here is geared to the almighty Junior Certificate Exam. Grades in
school don't matter, just the score on that one
exam. Consequently, the first two years, the JC
seems too remote for students to worry about,

and they goof off. The third year, they start to
worry and get serious—the JC is the ticket to
jobs and further education.
The issue of development in Botswana is
hard for a westerner like me to fathom, once
confronted 'with it. The value structure—of
cattle and sharing—works well, for the most part.
The "stark, striking contrast between rich and
poor," which we hear so much about, sounds
like a lot of trite rhetoric here, where it's more
subtle than in most places. I don't see starvation
in Mahalapye, but all it would take is a couple of
years of drought. Botswana's doing reasonably
well feeding its people—now--but everything
depends on each year's rain.
The government and the national economy are also fairly healthy at the moment,
backed by the longest-known diamond deposits
in the world. These mines, however, are controlled by South Africa's DeBeers, the "free"
world's diamond monopoly. In general, South
Africa dominates Botswana's economy. With
the exceptions of meat, sorghum, and m.ealiemeal, the vast majority of things found for sale
in Botswana's stores come from South Africa,
through South Africa, or from South African
controlled companies in Botswana. When it
comes to food, if it doesn't come from South
Africa, then it's Nestle's.
Those who knew me at Hopkins will
appreciate the irony—after four years of campaigning against South Africa and Nestle's on
the Hopkins campus, I come to Africa and find
myself unable to avoid them. Being in Botswana, I am more convinced than ever that those
two entities are fully deserving of every kind of
pressure that can possibly be brought to bear

business with them, or starve.

Palm Sunday: A Blivit Of Vonnegut
BY DAN VITALE
Palm Sunday, Kurt Vonnegut's
thirteenth book and second work of
non-fiction, is subtitled "An Autobiographical Collage." In the introduction,
Vonnegut describes what sort of structure
such a collage might have: "This book
combines the tidal power of a major
novel with the bone-rattling immediacy
of front-line journalism--which is old stuff
now, God knows, God knows. But I have
also intertwined the flashy enthusiasms of
musical theater, the lethal left jab of the
short story, the sachet of personal letters,
the oompah of American history, and
oratory in the bow-wow style." He then
goes on to propose a generic name for
this type of book: blivit, which he
loosely defines as "two pounds of shit in
a one-pound bag."
Actually, Palm Sunday falls
somewhere between the two descriptions.
In essence, it is a collection of essays,
speeches, fictions and non-fictions (some
previously published, others not), suspended from a running narrative which
attempts to keep them strung together.
The effect is not unlike laundry on a
clothesline; unfortunately, however,some
of the clothes are cleaner than others.
Among the more interesting
"bits" of the collage are: "The Noodle
Factory," a speech given in October 1976
during the dedication of a library at
Connecticut College; "How to Write
with Style," an essay written for an
International Paper Company advertising ,
campaign; a self-interview originally published in the Paris Review; and "Palm
Sunday," a sermon delivered at St.
Clement's Episcopal Church in New York
City in 1980. What makes these pieces so
fascinating is how well each reveals some
facet of Vonnegut's mind and character.
Each is a testament to the earnestness of

his ideas and the simple elegance of his
style. Some examples:
"Film is a perfect prescription for
people who will not or cannot read, and
have no imagination. Since they have no
imagination, those people can now be
shown actors and scenery instead--with
appropriate music and all that."
"We are members of an egalitarian
society, so there is no reason for us to
write, in case we are not classically
educated aristocrats, as though we were
classically educated aristocrats."
"If you make people laugh or cry
about little black marks on a sheet of
white paper, what is that but a practical
joke? All the great story lines are great
practical jokes that people fall for over
and over again."
When Palm Sunday reads like this.
it runs as smoothly as a new car. But the
book does have its share of awkward
moments and throwaways. Among these
are an alphabetical list of all of the
writers Vonnegut has met at least once,
which covers a full two and a half pages; a
rejected introduction to a new edition of
Swift's Gulliver's Travels; a mildly interesting short story titled "The Big Space
Fuck;" and a tedious treatment for a
musical comedy based on Stevenson's
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. One long
section, a family history covering four
generations of Vonneguts in America
(written not by Vonnegut but by John
Rauch, the husband of a cousin of
Vonnegut's father) is fairly illuminating
but very difficult to follow. At its most
self-indulgent, the book can be quite bad.
But for the most part, Palm
Sunday is an enjoyable read. One memorable section includes an impassioned
essay on Louis-Ferdinand Celine which
Vonnegut wrote as an introduction to the
Penguin editions of Celine's last three
novels; another features excerpts from

Vonnegut's master's thesis in anthropology, rejected by the University of Chicago,
in which he visually depicts the stories of
Cinderella, the creation, and Kafka's
"Metamorphosis," among others, by
plotting them as graphs on a coordinate
plane.
Thc finest selections included in
Palm Sunday are those concerning
freedom of the press, such as the letter
Vonnegut wrote to Charles McCarthy,
head of the school board of Drake,
North Dakota, which in 1973 banned
Vonnegut's novel Slaughterhouse-Five
from classrooms there; and an editorial
on censorship which appeared in the
Long Island edition of the New York
Times in March 1976. It is in these pieces
that we get the clearest image of what
Vonnegut's life and work mean to him.
He presents himself to McCarthy not so
much as an outraged author but as
a "planetary citizen," deeply hurt by the
suppression of ideas, while in the Times
he gives deeper and more universal
significance to his frustration:
"Whenever ideas are squashed in
this country, literate lovers of the American experiment write careful and intricate explanations of why all ideas must
be allowed to live. It is time for them to
realize that they are attempting to
explain America at its bravest and most
optimistic to orangutangs.
"From now on, I intend to limit
my discourse with dimwitted Savonarolas
to this advice: 'Have somebody read the
First Amendment to the United States
Constitution out loud to you, you
god-damned fool!"'
Overall, Palm Sunday is an uneven

work, an interesting premise slightly weak
in spots but potent nevertheless.
Vonnegut writes:
"By reading the
writings of the most interesting minds
in history, we meditate with our own
minds and theirs as well." This volume
offers the chance to meditate with the
mind of Kurt Vonnegut, writer and
planetary citizen, a chance which if
taken nourishes one's own mind in the
process.
